Submodules

api.core.activation module

Contains implementation of commonly used activation functions.

class api.core.activation.ELU(alpha=1, session=None, threshold=0)[source]

Bases: BaseActivation

Exponential Linear Unit activation function.

Fixes some ReLU issues, allows to learn faster.

Parameters:

alpha – leaky coefficient, defaults to 1

forward(x)[source]

Calculate elu.

class api.core.activation.ReLU(alpha=0, session=None, threshold=0)[source]

Bases: BaseActivation

(Leaky) Rectified Linear Unit activation function.

Solve gradient saturation problem, because output range is (-inf, inf). If the \(\alpha\) parameter is 0, there is “dead ReLU” problem where the function is completely inactive with negative input values.

Activation rule: \(max(\alpha x, x)\)

Parameters:

alpha – leaky coefficient, defaults to 0

forward(x)[source]

Calculate (l)relu.

class api.core.activation.Sigmoid(session=None, threshold=0)[source]

Bases: BaseActivation

Sigmoid activation function.

The output of a sigmoid function ranges between 0 and 1. Mostly used for models where we have to predict the “probability”.

Activation rule: \(\dfrac{1}{1 + e^{-x}}\)

forward(x)[source]

Calculate sigmoid.

class api.core.activation.Softmax(session=None, threshold=0)[source]

Bases: BaseActivation

Softmax activation function.

Mostly used for multi-class classification problems.

The activation rule is equivalent to:

exp / (ag.ops.sum(exp) + self.threshold)
forward(x)[source]

Calculate softmax.

class api.core.activation.Softplus(session=None, threshold=0)[source]

Bases: BaseActivation

Softplus activation function.

Relatively smoother version of the ReLU.

Activation rule: \(ln(1 + e^x)\)

forward(x)[source]

Calculate softplus.

class api.core.activation.Swish(beta=1, session=None, threshold=1e-32)[source]

Bases: BaseActivation

Self-Gated activation function.

Swish is unbounded above and bounded below. Unlike ReLU, the function is smooth and non-monotonic.

Activation rule: \(x*sigmoid(\beta x)\)

Parameters:

beta – either constant or trainable parameter, defaults to 1

forward(x)[source]

Calculate self-gated function.

class api.core.activation.Tanh(session=None, threshold=0)[source]

Bases: BaseActivation

Hyperbolic Tangent activation function.

This function is relatively similar to Sigmoid, but with one big advantage - function is 0-centric(output is in range (-1, 1)).

Activation rule: \(\dfrac{e^{x} - e^{-x}}{e^{x} + e^{-x}}\)

forward(x)[source]

Calculate tanh.

api.core.data module

Contains objects to work with data.

class api.core.data.Container(name, *args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: MutableMapping

Base dict-like container class.

To get an object use any of the three options

>>> container = Container(name=..., obj=3)
>>> container['obj']
3
>>> container.obj
3
>>> container('obj')
3

To get the compiled instance - use __call__ method

>>> container = Container(name=..., obj=lambda x: x)
>>> container('obj', compiled=True, x=3)
3

Note

if in __call__() the first argument is not str, then this object will be returned.

class api.core.data.Dataset(x_data, y_data, batch_size=1, dim=(1, 1), shuffle=True)[source]

Bases: object

Collection of data.

Implemented as an infinite generator. Use __len__ property to find out number of unique batches in one dataset.

Parameters:

  • x_data – input data

  • y_data – input data

  • batch_size – number of samples per one batch, defaults to 1

  • dim – x_data shape, while y_data shape will be equal to np.ones_like(dim), defaults to (1, 1)

  • shuffle – whether to shuffle data on epoch end

on_epoch_end()[source]

Do some postprocessing at the end of each epoch.

api.core.generic module

Contains Model definition.

class api.core.generic.Model(input_shape, session=None, name='model')[source]

Bases: Input

Neural network model.

At its core, the model is an Input layer with train/predict features and some modifications (see Model.forward() implementation).

The model creation procedure always looks the same:

  1. Initialize model with the expected shape of the input data

model = Model(input_shape=(1, 2))

  1. Add some layers to the model

model.add(Dense(3))
model.add(Dense(1))

  1. Model compilation.

Warning

Without this step, the model will not be able to train and predict.

model.compile(
    optimizer='gradient_descent',
    loss='mean_squared_error',
    metrics=['mean_absolute_error']
)

Now, the model is ready for training and prediction. For training, two options for printing results are possible (see the verbosity parameter of the Model.fit() function). In most cases, your code will look something like this:

model = Model(input_shape=(1, 2))

model.add(Dense(3, activation='sigmoid'))
model.add(Dense(1, activation='sigmoid'))

model.compile(
    optimizer='gradient_descent',
    loss='mean_squared_error',
    metrics=['mean_absolute_error']
)

x_train = np.array([[[0, 0]], [[0, 1]], [[1, 0]], [[1, 1]]])
y_train = np.array([[[0]], [[1]], [[1]], [[0]]])

model.fit(
    x_train, y_train,
    validation_data=[x_train, y_train],
    batch_size=4,
    epochs=10000,
    verbosity=1  # progress bar
)

For prediction, two options are possible:

  • Pass only the input data (x_test) to the function. In this case, the function will return only the predicted data.

model.predict(x_test)

  • Pass both x_test and y_test data. In this case, the function will return the predicted data and print the estimated metrics for that data

model.predict(x_test, y_test)
Parameters:

  • input_shape – tuple, input data shape (without batch size)

  • session – current session, if None - creates new, defaults to None

  • name – model name, defaults to ‘model’

add(layer)[source]

Add layer to the model.

Parameters:

layer – BaseLayer instance, layer to add

Raises:

ValueError – if layer is not of BaseLayer instance

build(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Initialize layer variables.

This method may be implemented by subclasses. It will be called before execution of forward(). Typically used to automatically define and validate I/O shapes.

compile(optimizer=None, loss=None, metrics=None)[source]

Compile model using given parameters.

Parameters:

  • optimizer – str or callable, model optimizer, defaults to gradient_descent

  • loss – str or callable, model loss, defaults to mean_squared_error

  • metrics – array of str or callable, additional metrics to evaluate, defaults to None

compute_metrics(data)[source]

Compute metrics for given data.

Parameters:

Returns:

dict with pairs metric.name:metric.value

fit(x_train, y_train, validation_data=None, validation_split=0.0, batch_size=1, shuffle=False, epochs=1, verbosity=1)[source]

Train model for a fixed number of epochs.

Note

To enable cross-validation, just pass validation_data or validation_split arguments. In this case, the validation_data argument will have priority.

Parameters:

  • x_train – input data

  • y_train – target (true) outputs

  • validation_data – array with length 2 - [x_val, y_val], defaults to None

  • validation_split – float in range (0, 1), the proportion of the train dataset to include in the validation split. For example, if validation split = 0.25, then the validation data will be 25% of the training data, defaults to 0.0

  • batch_size – number of samples per gradient update, defaults to 1

  • shuffle – whether to shuffle the data on epoch end, defaults to False

  • epochs – number of epochs to train model, defaults to 1

  • verbosity – 0 or 1, verbosity mode. 0 - silent mode, 1 - progress bar, defaults to 1

Raises:

ModelIsNotCompiledException – if this method was called without first compiling the model

forward(x, *args, **kwargs)[source]

Calculate output of the Input layer.

predict(x_test, y_test=None)[source]

Predict output with given input.

Parameters:

  • x_test – input data

  • y_test – target output. if the target data was passed to the function, not only will the predicted data be returned, but also the calculated metrics will be output to the console, defaults to None

Raises:

ModelIsNotCompiledException – if this method was called without first compiling the model

Returns:

predicted output

predict_step(data)[source]

Perform one predict step.

train_step(data)[source]

api.core.layers module

Contains layers implementations.

class api.core.layers.BaseLayer(session=None, name='Layer')[source]

Bases: object

Base layer class.

In most cases, to create a custom layer, it is enough to override the __init__(), build() and forward() methods:

  • build() should be used to lazily add new layer variables and will be called before the first call of self.forward() method by __call__() method, in other words, this method was created to automatically calculate input shapes for new layer variables.

  • forward() should be used to implement layer logic, an algorithm that will calculate the layer’s output.

It is possible to override the __call__() method, but this is not recommended.

So, a simple layer can be implemented as this:

class Linear(BaseLayer):

    def __init__(self, units=10, name='Linear'):
        super().__init__(session=None, name=name)
        self.units = units

        self.weights = None
        self.bias = None

    def build(self, input_shape):
        self.weights = initializers.random_normal(
            size=[input_shape[-1], self.units]
        )
        self.bias = initializers.ones(
            size=[1, self.units]
        )
        self._built = True
        return input_shape[-2], self.units

    def forward(self, value, *args, **kwargs):
        return value @ self.weights + self.bias
Parameters:

  • session – current session, if None, create a new one, defaults to None

  • name – name of the layer, defaults to ‘Layer’

add_variable(name=None, shape=None, initializer=None, trainable=False)[source]

Add new layer value.

An initializer is expected to be of type BaseInitializer, which returns a variable. If None, use xavier_uniform as default.

New variables will be initialized with the name: layer.name/var_name.

class api.core.layers.Dense(units=1, activation=None, weight_initializer=None, bias_initializer=None, use_bias=True, session=None, name='Dense', **kwargs)[source]

Bases: BaseLayer

Dense (or Fully Connected) layer.

The output of this layer is computed as activate(X @ W + b), where X is layer input, W - layer weights, b - layer bias, activate - some activation function. Bias and activate are optional and can be disabled when creating the layer.

Parameters:

  • units – number of layer units, defaults to 1

  • activation – activation function, if None - the activation function will not be applied to the resulting formula, defaults to None

  • weight_initializer – str or callable, name of the function (or function itself) used to initialize the weights, if None - `xavier_uniform will be used as default, defaults to None

  • bias_initializer – str or callable, name of the function (or function itself) used to initialize the biases, if None - zeros will be used as default, defaults to None

  • use_bias – whether to use a bias when the forward pass

build(input_shape)[source]

Initialize layer variables.

This method may be implemented by subclasses. It will be called before execution of forward(). Typically used to automatically define and validate I/O shapes.

forward(value, *args, **kwargs)[source]

Calculate output of the layer.

class api.core.layers.Input(input_shape, batch_size=None, session=None, name='Input')[source]

Bases: BaseLayer

Input layer.

By default, the input layer is required to know the size of the input data. When calling a layer without arguments, a Placeholder with the input_shape mentioned above will be created.

If the Input layer was called with some argument x (in other words, the input data was passed directly) - it will return a Variable with that data

Parameters:

input_shape – fixed shape of future data, at least 1d

Raises:

ValueError – if input_shape dimension < 1

forward(x, *args, **kwargs)[source]

Calculate output of the Input layer.

class api.core.layers.InputShape(batch_input_shape)[source]

Bases: object

Contains information about the shape of the input data.

If the length of the batch_input_shape is less than 2, then batch will be set to None. Otherwise, the first element of the batch_input_shape will be the batch size. The rest of the batch_input_shape elements are considered input_shape.

Parameters:

batch_input_shape – array that contains at least 2 elements, the first element is batch size and all the rest are input shape.

Raises:

ValueError – array length is less than 2

api.core.loss module

Contains implementation of commonly used loss functions.

Regression:

  • (Root) Mean Squared Error

  • Mean Absolute Error

  • Mean Bias Error

  • Huber Loss

Binary Classification:

  • Likelihood Loss

  • Binary Cross Entropy

  • (Squared) Hinge Loss

Multinomial Classification:

  • Categorical Cross Entropy

  • Kullback-Leibler Divergence

class api.core.loss.BCE(name='binary_cross_entropy', session=None, threshold=1e-32)[source]

Bases: BaseLoss

Binary Cross Entropy.

Modification of the LHL using logarithms. This allows for more severe penalties for large errors.

forward(y_pred, y_true)[source]

Calculate BCE.

class api.core.loss.CCE(name='categorical_cross_entropy', session=None, threshold=1e-32)[source]

Bases: BaseLoss

Categorical Cross Entropy.

Used for multinomial classification. Similar formula as in the BCE, but with one extra step. The output label is assigned one-hot category encoding value in form of 0s and 1. Calculate the loss for every pair of targets and predictions and return the mean

forward(y_pred, y_true)[source]

Calculate CCE.

class api.core.loss.Hinge(name='hinge', session=None, threshold=0)[source]

Bases: BaseLoss

Hinge Loss.

Primarily was developed to evaluate SVM models. Incorrect or less confident right predictions are more penalized with Hinge Loss

Warning

To apply Hinge Loss, classes must be marked as 1 and -1 (not 0)

forward(y_pred, y_true)[source]

Calculate HL.

class api.core.loss.Huber(name='huber', delta=1, session=None, threshold=0)[source]

Bases: BaseLoss

Huber Loss.

Combination of MAE and MSE. This loss applies MAE for values that fits under the expected values, and MSE is applied to outliers.

Parameters:

delta – a number, point where two functions are connected, defaults to 1

forward(y_pred, y_true)[source]

Calculate Huber loss.

class api.core.loss.KLD(name='kullback_leibler_divergence', session=None, threshold=1e-32)[source]

Bases: BaseLoss

Kullback-Leibler Divergence.

Similar to CCE, but considers the probability of occurrence of observations. Useful when classes are not balanced.

forward(y_pred, y_true)[source]

Calculate KLD.

class api.core.loss.LHL(name='likelihood', session=None, threshold=0)[source]

Bases: BaseLoss

Likelihood Loss.

Multiplication of the probability for the ground truth labels. If the true class is [1], we use the output probability, otherwise if the true class is [0], we use 1-output probability. Mostly used for binary classification.

forward(y_pred, y_true)[source]

Calculate LHL.

class api.core.loss.MAE(name='mean_absolute_error', session=None, threshold=0)[source]

Bases: BaseLoss

Mean Absolute Error.

Finds the averaged absolute difference between predicted and actual values. Mostly used for regression problems.

forward(y_pred, y_true)[source]

Calculate MAE.

class api.core.loss.MBE(name='mean_bias_error', session=None, threshold=0)[source]

Mean Bias Error.

Finds the averaged difference between predicted and actual values. Mostly used for regression problems.

api.core.optimizers module

Contains implementation of optimizers.

class api.core.optimizers.Adadelta(learning_rate=1, rho=0.9, epsilon=1e-16, trainable_variables=None, session=None, name='Adadelta')[source]

Bases: BaseOptimizer

Optimizer that implements the Adadelta algorithm.

Adadelta is a more robust extension of Adagrad that adapts learning rates based on a moving window of gradient updates, instead of accumulating all past gradients. This way, Adadelta continues learning even when many updates have been done. Compared to Adagrad, in the original version of Adadelta you don’t have to set an initial learning rate. In this implementation learning_rate can be set

Parameters:

  • learning_rate – hyperparameter, some small value, defaults to 1

  • rho – hyperparameter, the decay rate, defaults to 0.9

  • epsilon – small floating point value used to maintain numerical stability, defaults to 1e-16

apply_gradient(x, grad)[source]

Apply computed gradients to trainable variables using update rule.

Parameters:

  • x – node, value to update

  • grad – gradient of the x node

Returns:

update operation

Initialize optimizer variables.

This method should be implemented and called by subclasses.

class api.core.optimizers.Adagrad(learning_rate=0.1, initial_accumulator_value=0.1, epsilon=1e-16, trainable_variables=None, session=None, name='Adagrad')[source]

Bases: BaseOptimizer

Optimizer that implements the Adaptive Gradient algorithm.

Adagrad is an optimizer with parameter-specific learning rates, which are adapted relative to how frequently a parameter gets updated during training. The more updates a parameter receives, the smaller the updates.

Parameters:

  • learning_rate – hyperparameter, some small value, defaults to 0.1

  • initial_accumulator_value – hyperparameter, value in range [0, 1], defaults to 0

  • epsilon – small floating point value used to maintain numerical stability, defaults to 1e-16

apply_gradient(x, grad)[source]

class api.core.optimizers.Adam(learning_rate=0.1, beta_1=0.9, beta_2=0.999, epsilon=1e-16, amsgrad=False, trainable_variables=None, session=None, name='Adam')[source]

Bases: BaseOptimizer

Optimizer that implements the Adam algorithm.

Adam optimization is a stochastic gradient descent method that is based on adaptive estimation of first-order and second-order moments.

Parameters:

  • learning_rate – hyperparameter, some small value, defaults to 0.1

  • beta_1 – hyperparameter, the exponential decay rate for the 1st moment estimates, defaults to 0.9.

  • beta_2 – hyperparameter, the exponential decay rate for the 2nd moment estimates, defaults to 0.9.

  • epsilon – small floating point value used to maintain numerical stability, defaults to 1e-16

  • amsgrad – whether to apply AMSGrad variant of this algorithm from the paper “On the Convergence of Adam and beyond”, defaults to False

Adamax, a variant of Adam based on the infinity norm, is a first-order gradient-based optimization method

  • epsilon – small floating point value used to maintain numerical stability, defaults to 1e-16

class api.core.optimizers.BaseOptimizer(trainable_variables, session=None, name=None, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Operation

Base optimizer class.

Basically, every optimizer is an Operation. So, in most cases, to create a custom optimizer, it is enough to override the __init__(), build() and apply_gradient() methods:

  • build() should be used to add new optimizer variables and will be called inside the self.forward() method (in general, this method was created to add some inner context to each optimizer, e.g. momentums). Each child implementation should call the parent’s build() method at the beginning.

  • apply_gradient() should be used to implement optimizer logic, an algorithm that will be used to update a variable.

Warning

Any other methods are not recommended to be overridden.

So, a simple optimizer can be implemented as this:

class SimpleGD(BaseOptimizer):

    def __init__(self, learning_rate=0.1, trainable=None, name='gd'):
        super().__init__(trainable, session=None, name=name)
        self.learning_rate = learning_rate

        self._lr = None
        self._built = False

    def build(self, var_list):
        super().build(var_list)
        if self._built:
            return

        self._lr = self.add_variable(
            self.learning_rate, 'learning_rate'
        )
        self._built = True

    def apply_gradient(self, x, grad):
        return autograd.ops.assign_add(x, -self._lr * grad)
Parameters:

  • trainable_variables – variables to optimize, defaults to None

  • session – current session, if None - creates new, defaults to None

  • name – optimizer name

add_variable(init_val, var_name=None)[source]

class api.core.optimizers.GradientDescent(learning_rate=0.001, momentum=0, nesterov=False, trainable_variables=None, session=None, name='GradientDescent')[source]

Bases: BaseOptimizer

Gradient Descent optimizer.

Update rule for parameter w with gradient g when momentum is 0:

w = w - learning_rate * g

Update rule when momentum is larger than 0:

velocity = momentum * velocity - learning_rate * g
w = w + velocity

When nesterov=True, this rule becomes:

velocity = momentum * velocity - learning_rate * g
w = w + momentum * velocity - learning_rate * g
Parameters:

  • learning_rate – hyperparameter, some small value, defaults to 0.001

  • momentum – hyperparameter, value in range [0, 1], defaults to 0

  • nesterov – whether to apply Nesterov momentum, defaults to False

apply_gradient(x, grad)[source]

Apply computed gradients to trainable variables using update rule.

Parameters:

  • x – node, value to update

  • grad – gradient of the x node

update operation

build(var_list)[source]

Initialize optimizer variables.

This method should be implemented and called by subclasses.

class api.core.optimizers.RMSProp(learning_rate=0.1, momentum=0, rho=0.95, epsilon=1e-16, centered=False, trainable_variables=None, session=None, name='RMSProp')[source]

Bases: BaseOptimizer

Optimizer that implements the Root Mean Squared Propagation algorithm.

This implementation of RMSProp uses plain momentum, not Nesterov momentum.

The centered version additionally maintains a moving average of the gradients, and uses that average to estimate the variance.

Parameters:

  • learning_rate – hyperparameter, some small value, defaults to 0.1

  • momentum – hyperparameter, value in range [0, 1], defaults to 0

  • rho – hyperparameter, the decay rate, defaults to 0.9

  • epsilon – small floating point value used to maintain numerical stability, defaults to 1e-16

  • centered – if True, gradients are normalized by the estimated variance of the gradient; if False, by the uncentered second moment. Setting this to True may help with training, but is slightly more expensive in terms of computation and memory, defaults to False

apply_gradient(x, grad)[source]

  • grad – gradient of the x node

api.core.utils module

Contains useful frequently used objects.

api.core.utils.at_least3d(array)[source]

View inputs as arrays with at least three dimensions.

Unlike the numpy counterpart, this function has the following behaviour: a 1-D array of shape (N,) becomes a view of shape (1, N, 1), and a 2-D array of shape (M, N) becomes a view of shape (1, M, N).

Parameters:

array – array-like sequence

Returns:

an array with ndim >= 3
